question: Question_01_(l)
statement:
If

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f'(a)\end{align*}

exists, then

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \rightarrow a} f(x)\end{align*}

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  must exist, but there is not enough information to determine it
  exactly.
\item
  equals f(a).
\item
  equals f'(a).
\item
  might not exist.
\item
  None of the above.
\end{enumerate}
sols:
If $f$ is differentiable at \emph{a}, then $f$ must also be continuous at
\emph{a}. Hence, the limit

\begin{align*}\lim_{x\to a} f(x)\end{align*}

exists and is equal to $f$\emph{(a)}. The correct answer is therefore
\textbf{B}.
hints:
If a function is differentiable at $a$, must it also be continuous at
$a$?
